review.title: A Brief State of the Art for Ontology Authoring
review.abstract: One of the main challenges for building the Semantic web is Ontology Authoring. Controlled Natural Languages CNLs offer a user friendly means for non-experts to author ontologies. This paper provides a snapshot of the state-of-the-art for the core CNLs for ontology authoring and reviews their respective evaluations.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The Semantic Web seeks to expand the current Web by enriching information with well-defined meanings that can be processed by machine [B-Lee et al., 2001]. This process depends heavily on the existence of ontologies that describe the area of interest. Formal data representation can be a significant deterrent for laymen or small organizations that develop ontologies and then want to benefit from the introduction of semantic technologies. Controlled natural languages are defined as "subgroups of natural languages whose grammars and dictionaries have been restricted to reduce or eliminate both ambiguity and complexity" [Schwitter and Tilbrook, 2004]. The aim of this paper is to provide a snapshot of the state of the art, the snippets of which have been limited to reduce or eliminate the ambiguity and complexity of knowledge.

sections.heading: 2.3 Other CNLs
sections.text: It is essentially an extension of the Controlled Language for Ontology Editing CLONE [Funk et al., 2007], but it is much more powerful in terms of grammar expressivity and ontology authoring skills. Like CLONE, Rabbit is implemented with the GATE framework [Cunningham, 2002]. Rabbit was developed by the National Cartography Agency in the UK - Ordnance Survey. Rabbit can be converted to OWL5 to provide natural language support for ontology authoring. OWL development is not the primary goal of Rabbit. It is primarily a vehicle for collecting, displaying and communicating knowledge in a form that is easily understood by domain experts.
